messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: 1 Introduction

Paper Abstract: 

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Multi camera image tracking",
        "Multi-camera multi-object tracking by robust hough-based homography projections",
        "Multi-target multi-camera tracking by tracklet-to-target assignment",
        "Multi-person 3d pose estimation in crowded scenes based on multi-view geometry",
        "Cross-view tracking for multi-human 3d pose estimation at over 100 fps",
        "Synergetic reconstruction from 2d pose and 3d motion for wide-space multi-person video motion capture in the wild",
        "Fast and robust multi-person 3d pose estimation and tracking from multiple views",
        "Voxeltrack: Multi-person 3d human pose estimation and tracking in the wild",
        "Multi-camera multi-target tracking with space-time-view hyper-graph",
        "The mta dataset for multi-target multi-camera pedestrian tracking by weighted distance aggregation",
        "Towards a bayesian approach to robust finding correspondences in multiple view geometry environments",
        "Multicamera people tracking with a probabilistic occupancy map",
        "3d pictorial structures revisited: Multiple human pose estimation",
        "Tackling multiple object tracking with complicated motionsâ€”re-designing the integration of motion and appearance",
        "Motr: End-to-end multiple-object tracking with transformer",
        "Global tracking transformers",
        "Strongsort: Make deepsort great again",
        "Hard to track objects with irregular motions and similar appearances? make it easier by buffering the matching space",
        "Soccernet 2022 challenges results",
        "Fast and robust multi-person 3d pose estimation from multiple views",
        "Branch-and-price global optimization for multi-view multi-target tracking",
        "4d association graph for realtime multi-person motion capture using multiple video cameras",
        "Simple online and realtime tracking",
        "Parametric and non-parametric unsupervised cluster analysis",
        "Multiple view geometry in computer vision",
        "Random sample consensus: a paradigm for model fitting with applications to image analysis and automated cartography",
        "Learnable triangulation of human pose",
        "Distinctive image features from scale-invariant keypoints",
        "Algorithms for hierarchical clustering: an overview",
        "Simple online and realtime tracking with a deep association metric",
        "Wildtrack: A multi-camera hd dataset for dense unscripted pedestrian detection",
        "Mmptrack: Large-scale densely annotated multi-camera multiple people tracking benchmark",
        "Lmgp: Lifted multicut meets geometry projections for multi-camera multi-object tracking",
        "MOTChallenge 2015: Towards a benchmark for multi-target tracking",
        "Mot16: A benchmark for multi-object tracking",
        "A bayesian filter for multi-view 3d multi-object tracking with occlusion handling",
        "Real-time 3d deep multi-camera tracking",
        "Evaluating multiple object tracking performance: the clear mot metrics",
        "Performance measures and a data set for multi-target, multi-camera tracking",
        "Yolox: Exceeding yolo series in 2021",
        "A strong baseline and batch normalization neck for deep person re-identification",
        "3d pictorial structures for multiple human pose estimation",
        "Multiple human pose estimation with temporally consistent 3d pictorial structures",
        "Multiple human 3d pose estimation from multiview images",
        "Faster voxelpose: Real-time 3d human pose estimation by orthographic projection",
        "Voxelpose: Towards multi-camera 3d human pose estimation in wild environment",
        "Realtime multi-person 2d pose estimation using part affinity fields",
        "Progressive domain adaptation for robot vision person re-identification",
        "Remots: Self-supervised refining multi-object tracking and segmentation",
        "Remot: A model-agnostic refinement for multiple object tracking"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in 1 Introduction, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
